block.p: Best Bet

On the way to a run Off Broadway after three regional theater productions, ''Love, Janis: The Songs, the Letters, the Soul of Janis Joplin'' comes to the Bay Street Theater in Sag Harbor on Wednesday. Conceived, adapted and directed by Randal Myler, a 1999 Tony award nominee, and based on ''Love, Janis,'' a book by the singer's sister, Laura Joplin, the theater piece blends the songs that rocked the 1960's with letters Joplin wrote. Running through Aug. 6, it stars Catherine Curtin in the title role, and the singers Cathy Richardson and Andra C. Mitrovich. Sam Andrew, the founder and lead guitarist for Big Brother and the Holding Company, Joplin's original band, is the musical director. (631) 725-9500.

Summer Blues

The blues invade the East End on Friday when the free ''Riverhead Blues Festival'' opens its three-day stand from 6 to 11 p.m. with a lineup featuring the Kerry Kearney Band. On Saturday, from 3 to 11 p.m., Sam Taylor and His Band, Heather (Lil Mama) Hardy and Little Curtis headline, while Rod Piazza and the Mighty Flyers star next Sunday from 1 to 6 p.m. The music will be performed on two stages along the Peconic Riverfront. (631) 727-3200.
Musical Theater Salute

When it comes to wrapping musical revues into neat packages, little succeeds as well as singling out composers for tributes. Guild Hall's ''American Musical Theater Salutes Series'' begins today at 8 p.m. with ''Happy Birthday, Noel Coward.'' Lee Davis is host to the performers Steve Ross, Lewis Cleale and Lorna Dallas. Arthur Laurents, Tony Walton and the Rodgers family will get similar treatment. (631) 324-4050.
Film Festival

With 47 films, including the highly touted ''Steal This Movie,'' about the Yippie leader Abbie Hoffman, which will be screened Saturday before its New York premiere on Aug. 25, the 2000 Stony Brook Film Festival opens Wednesday with the New York premiere of ''Wildflowers'' a drama with Daryl Hannah and Eric Roberts. The festival, at the Staller Center on the Stony Brook campus of the State University, concludes on July 29 with ''The Ice Rink.'' (631) 632-2787.
Festival Finale

The Music Festival of the Hamptons ends its three-week run this week with seven concerts. Today there are two: the Children's Orchestra Society Chamber Players at 11 a.m., and the Atlantic Chamber Orchestra at 8 p.m. Mid-week action moves from the Festival Tent on Snakehollow Road in Bridgehampton to Guild Hall's John Drew Theater in East Hampton at 8 p.m. for Philip Fowke and Daniel Beliavsky, pianists, tomorrow and Thursday, respectively; and Phillip Quint, violinist, and Tatiana Goncharova, pianist, on Friday. Back in Bridgehampton, the final Saturday offers ''Songs and Arias,'' with Fredrika Brillembourg, mezzo-soprano, and Scott Dunn, pianist, at 5 p.m. At 8 p.m. there is ''A Celebration of Jazz, Broadway and Cabaret,'' with Mary Cleere Haran, a singer, and a tribute to the composer Richard Adler. (800) 644-4418.
Another Festival

While one music festival ends this week, yet another begins: the C. W. Post Chamber Music Festival, an intensive three-week session for young professionals and students in Brookville. The Pierrot Consort, the ensemble in residence, performs the festival's first concert at 8 p.m. Friday at Hillwood Recital Hall. Through Aug. 4, master classes, recitals and concerts will be open to the public. (516) 299-2103.
Around the Parks

This week provides fans of concerts al fresco with enough variety to satisfy the most varied tastes. Today at 3 p.m., the Concert Pops of Long Island plays at Babylon Town Hall on East Sunrise Highway in North Lindenhurst (631-893-2119), while tomorrow the Chiclettes, a rock ensemble, appears at 8 p.m. at Hewlett Point Park (516-489-4849). Tuesday is band night, with a choice between the North Shore Pops Concert Band at 7 p.m. at Clark Botanic Garden in Albertson (516-327-3110), or Johnny Maestro and the Brooklyn Bridge at 8 p.m. at Burns Park in Massapequa (516-797-7900).

Wednesday brings the gospel sounds of Lee Cloud and the Northenaires to Hendrickson Avenue Park in Elmont at 8 p.m. (516--489-4849), or the Thunderbird Sisters, an American Indian group, to Agawam Park in Southampton at 6:45 p.m. (631-287-4300). The Atlantic Wind Symphony appears at 7:30 p.m. Thursday on the Village Green in Westhampton Beach (631-288-0780), while the Community Park in Bethpage welcomes Linda Ipanema and the Dixiecats at 8 p.m. (516-797-7900). Come Friday and the Sol y Sombra Spanish Dance Company performs ''flamenco with a Latin-American accent'' at 8:30 p.m. at Heckscher Park in Huntington (631-271-8423). Finally, on Saturday, Jessica Andrews, the country singer, and Sons of the Desert head the ''WMJC Country Show'' bill at 8 p.m. at Lakeside Theater in Eisenhower Park, East Meadow (516-572-0223).
Nostalgia Reigns

Five concerts featuring the pop past make this a good week to get your nostalgia kicks. For example, on Tuesday at 8 p.m. at Echo Park in West Hempstead, David Grayson offers ''Be My Love: a Tribute to Mario Lanza.'' (516) 489-4849. Then on Wednesday, Julius LaRosa appears at 8 p.m. at the Community Park in Woodbury. (516) 797-7900 On Thursday Jeannie Romero and King Kai and the Creoles perform ''The Music of Connie Francis and Elvis'' at 8 p.m. at Newbridge Road Park in Bellmore. (516) 489-4849. Rounding out the free-concert lineup, Guy Lombardo's Royal Canadians appear on Friday at 8 p.m. at Hicksville High School. (516) 797-7900. In a triple play, the Westbury Music Fair brings Dion and Little Anthony and the Imperials to its stage at 8 p.m. Friday and Saturday to reprise their hits. (516) 334-0800.
Regis and Kathie Lee

As most of the Western world knows, Kathie Lee Gifford is leaving the television show ''Live With Regis and Kathie Lee.'' But apparently not before she and Regis Philbin, her co-host, who has lately been creating millionaires, offer ''The Farewell Concert.'' Said to be ''the last time'' the duo will ''perform together live,'' the show pulls into the Westbury Music Fair on Brush Hollow Road at 8 p.m. on Thursday. (516) 334-0800.
Free Choices

TODAY -- In one of those periodic quirks of fate -- and programming -- the classics dominate the musical scene with three concerts on tap: performing works that span four centuries, the Long Island Brass Guild appears at 2 p.m. at Bayard Cutting Arboretum in Oakdale (631) 224-5440; the Polezhayev Family, four violinists and pianists who emigrated to Long Island from Russia, appear at 8 p.m. at Morgan Park in Glen Cove (516) 759-6970; and Elise Sobol, pianist, joined by a trio of colleagues, offers a ''Summer Serenade'' of Bach, Gershwin and Mozart, at 8 p.m. at Mattlin Middle School in Plainview (516) 797-7900.

TOMORROW -- Making the rounds of summer parks series, Plaza Theatrical Production's version of ''The King and I'' hits Allen Park in Farmingdale at 8 p.m. (516) 797-7900. The Rodgers and Hammerstein classic will be repeated on Wednesday at 7:30 p.m. at the Islip Grange on Broadway in Sayville. (631) 224-5430.

TUESDAY -- ''Neighborhood Night in Oyster Bay,'' a weekly program that invites visitors to sample five local institutions that usually charge admission, gets under way with Raynham Hall Museum on West Main Street, opening its doors at 6 p.m. for tours, music by Long Island Sound and children's games. (516) 922-6464.

THURSDAY -- The Disney Channel takes over the Jones Beach Theater in Wantagh for ''PremEARS in the Park,'' a mini-movie festival for families. Starting at 6 p.m. there will be games, live performances by acts like BBMak and Hoku and appearances by Disney characters. At sundown an original movie, ''Quints,'' will be screened before it makes it debut on Aug. 18 on the Disney Channel. (516) 221-1000.
